page.title: 15Beetham Now And Then
page.content: We know from old records that the staple diet consisted mainly of oats. The Saxon name "Haverbrack" tells us that they were grown locally. There were oak woods and hazel trees. Some sheep grazed on the hillsides. The local people had jobs in the immediate vicinity. There was a village pond and a small cluster of houses by the church. At the present time the land is used mainly for grazing and for caravan parks. There are lots of hazel, sycamore and evergreens. There has been a limited increase in housing. The paper mill employs some local people but many commute to near by towns. The area is a well known tourist attraction.
